text: Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup
Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”
Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.
Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside.
When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
Let your child make up the next sentence
Then you make up a sentence
Take turns until you have a wonderful new story
Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
Ask your child what was their favourite part of the story!
Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds.
Ask your child “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?
Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out.
Now let them choose a super power for you
Make sure you act it out too!
Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane
Say them to your child and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
Now think of three more situations or ask your child to do it for you
Lie on your tummies and pretend your index fingers are a wiggly worm.
With your other hand make a worm house by making a circle with your fingers and thumb and place it on the floor.
Call out an instruction for your finger to touch, like “Worms on noses” or “Worms on ears”
When you call out “Worms go home”, your wiggly worm has to find a worm house as quickly as possible.
The last worm to find a home calls out the instructions next.
Keep playing until you feel rejuvenated from lying down.

If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe location, like a crib, and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
1. Take a deep breath before you respond.
2. Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
3. Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
4. Reassure your child that you are there for them.
5. You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
6. Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
7. Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.

Hi! When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!

text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!
Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.

Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Physical exercise is a great way to reduce stress and keep healthy. You can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.
Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
Take a moment to reflect on your experience.
Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
Would you like some  other relaxation activities?

text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress.
Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs
First person does a dance move and everyone else copies.
Everyone takes turns being the leader
This game can be played in pairs or even as a group
Stand facing each other or in a circle
One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead
Play music or someone sings a song, and everyone dances
When the music stops, everyone must freeze
Last person still dancing becomes the judge for the next round
Animal dance: Same as above but when the music stops, call out a name of an animal, and everyone has to become that animal
Everyone runs around the room or garden.  Make sure the space is large enough and safe
At any time, someone can stop somewhere and say, “When you get over here, you do this!”
What you do can be anything: push-ups, singing a song, crying, jumping…
The more you play, there are more and more things to do in more and more places.
Each person can decide where to go when.
It’s fun to interact with other people who are doing the same thing as you!
